We find using simple code coverage (method entry profiling) is a cheap and
easy way to double-check your tests and helps ensure you really did test
everything you intended to test with your test cases. I believe Joseph
Pelrine, possibly in this lecture
http://oopsla.acm.org/ap/tutorials/tut66.html, mentioned several groups
using XP who thought they were doing a fine job of writing tests, only to
find on running their tests under a code coverage profiler (SilverMark's
Test Mentor with code coverage profiling turned on), that they had missed a
number of important functional variations/methods. The way I look at it, we
test because we admit we are fallible. Any tool or technique that, when used
properly, can help guard against that fallibility when we write our tests
must be a good thing.

> Is coverage really that important?  The directive is to "Test
> everything that could possibly break", not "Test everything".
>
> Unit Tests give you great benefits in productivity and quality.
> I have worked on XP teams that measured both quality and
> productivity.  Unit Testing and XP does improve both!  However,
> there comes a point where more Unit Tests only marginally
> increases quality while not increasing productivity (even
> negatively impacting productivity).  Developers should question
> the value of creating more Unit Tests.  If you are not careful,
> you can get into a "Test everything" mode and kill productivity.
>
> Since Coverage metrics can lead the team to focus on "Test
> Everything", it isn't a great measurement.  Instead, focus on
> "things that could break" and you will continue to gain both
> increased productivity and quality.   Only use Coverage tools to
> reveal something that could break.  Using coverage as a metric is
> a poor practice.  I suggest using quality metrics instead (i.e.
> number of Unit Tests and number of passing Functional Tests)
>
